title-group.article-title: A bridging model prediction of the ultimate strength of composite laminates subjected to triaxial loads

contrib-group.aff: School of Aerospace Engineering & Applied Mechanics, Tongji University, China

author-notes.corresp: Zheng-Ming Huang, School of Aerospace Engineering & Applied Mechanics, Tongji University, 1239 Siping Road, Shanghai 200092, China Email: huangzm@mail.tongji.edu.cn

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: Evaluation of Theories for Predicting Failure in Polymer Composite Laminates Under 3-D States of Stress: Part A of the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II)

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: A pseudo three-dimensional laminate theory is incorporated with the three-dimensional bridging model, based on micromechanics formulae, to predict failure under triaxial loads. A lamina failure is considered to occur as long as any of its constituents has failed. A laminate ultimate failure is assumed to take place when the fibres have failed or when the resin has failed in compression. In order to account for the effect of a three-dimensional compression on increasing the load-carrying ability of a resin material, a modified maximum compressive stress failure criterion is introduced. The methodology was used successfully to solve all the 12 challenging test cases of the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The ultimate strength of a composite laminate is a most important factor to be considered in a composite design. Over the past decades lots of efforts have been made to predict the ultimate strength of the laminates. From 1993 to 2004, Soden, Hinton and Kaddour organized the First World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-I)1 to compare predictive capabilities of a number of most important strength theories in the current usage. The exercise has given a good suggestion and guidance for composite designers although only bi-axial in-plane loads were considered in that exercise. However, composites have been used more and more widely in various engineering fields, which may be subjected to more complicated loads. As such, the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II) is organized to check the predictive capacities of the theories for laminates under some kinds of triaxial loads.

As noted previously,1 the majority of the failure theories are developed based on macro-mechanical approaches, which make use of some phenomenological failure criteria for a unidirectional lamina. Comparing to those theories, micromechanical approaches have the features that only the properties of constituent materials of the composites are required, and that it is easy to determine the stresses in the constituent materials and to identify failure modes. Bridging model is a recently developed micromechanical theory2–4 that can be modified to apply to laminates subjected to triaxial loads. Based on the bridging model, the nonlinear behavior of the laminates due to both an inelastic deformation of the constituent materials and a progressive failure process can be predicted. Thermal residual stresses can be tailored easily. The ultimate strengths of the laminates due to the failure of the constituent materials can be determined and thus the modes of failures can be identified automatically.

The aim of this article is to analyze the tri-axial strengths of a number of unidirectional laminae and multidirectional laminates by using the bridging model. A pseudo three-dimensional (3D) laminate theory incorporated with the 3D bridging model formulae is used to perform this analysis. A lamina failure is attained when any of its constituents has failed. A partial stiffness discount scheme, in which the modulus of resin material is replaced by 1% of its original data, is applied to the failed lamina. A laminate ultimate failure is considered to occur if and only if there is a fiber failure (tensile or compressive failure) or there is a resin compressive failure. In order to account for the effect of a 3D compression on increasing the load-carrying ability of a resin material, a modified maximum compressive stress failure criterion is used for the first time in this article to detect its compressive failure. All of the exercise problems, specified by Kaddour and Hinton, are analyzed and the predicted results are reported in figures and data tables.

sec.title: Simulation procedure
sec.p:
An incremental solution strategy is applied to simulate a lamina or laminate. Similarly as done in Huang,4 the simulation procedure for a multidirectional laminate (Figure 1) can be divided into two steps, laminate analysis and lamina analysis. In the laminate analysis, the stresses shared by each lamina can be determined by using a laminate theory, but the overall stiffness of the laminate should be known a priori. Initially, this stiffness can be defined using elastic properties of the constituent materials based on the bridging model and the laminate theory. When the resin undergoes an inelastic deformation, the stiffness must be updated from a lamina analysis. In the lamina analysis, the internal stresses in the fibers and resin are obtained in terms of the bridging model, and a failure criterion is used to check whether any of the constituent materials fails. If a lamina failure is attained, a stiffness discount may be applied to the failed lamina. More details on the lamina and laminate analyses are described in the following sections, ‘Lamina theory’ and ‘Laminate theory’, respectively. Figure 1.
Simulation procedure for a multidirectional laminate.

sec.title: Stress calculation
sec.p:
Consider a unidirectional (UD) composite lamina, which is made of transversely isotropic fibers and an isotropic resin. In order to deal with any nonlinear response in a unified manner, an incremental approach is adopted as schematically shown in Figure 2, although this is not necessary for a linearly elastic material. Suppose that the lamina is subjected to a combination of a mechanical load {dσj} = {dσ11, dσ22, dσ33, dσ23, dσ13, dσ12} and a temperature variation dT. Positive directions of these mechanical loads are illustrated in Figure 3. In terms of the bridging model, the internal stress increments generated in the fiber and resin materials can be calculated through equations (1) (1.1){dσi f}=[Bij]{dσj}+{bi f}dT (1.2){dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT where [Aij] is a bridging matrix, [Bj]=(Vf[I]+Vm[Aij])-1, {bi f} and {bi m} are called thermal stress concentration factors of the fibers and the resin, respectively. Some information relevant to the development of the bridging model is given in Appendix 2. More details on the bridging model formulae can be found in Huang.2–4 Figure 2.
Schematic diagram showing an incremental approach for a unidirectional lamina. Figure 3.
A lamina local coordinate system with positive load directions.

The total stresses in the various materials can be simply updated through (2){dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT where K represents a load step number. [σij](0)(= [0]), [σij f](0), and [σij m](0) are the initial (residual) stresses in the composite lamina, the fiber, and the resin materials, respectively. For example, [σij f](0), and [σij m](0) may be thermal residual stresses generated in the constituent materials, which can be determined through a thermal analysis as described in Appendix 2.

sec.title: Failure criteria
sec.p: A lamina failure is considered to occur as long as any of its constituent materials attains a failure stress state. The criterion used in this article to detect a constituent tensile failure is the same as that used in Huang.3,4 Namely, the tensile failure of either the fiber or the resin material is attained if (3.1)σeq t≥σu where (3.2)σeq t={σ(1),σ(3)<0,[(σ(1))q+(σ(2))q+(σ(3))q]1q,whenσ(3)≥0,1<q≤∞

In the above, σu is the uniaxial tensile strength of the material, q is a power index which is introduced to account for a reduction in the material load-carrying capacity due to a tri-axial tension in comparison with a uniaxial tension, σ(1), σ(2) and σ(3) are the three principal stresses of the constituent which satisfy that σ(1)≥σ(2)≥σ(3). These principal stresses are the solutions to the following equation (4)det([σ11σ12σ13σ21σ22σ23σ31σ32σ33]-σ[I])=0
Throughout this article, the power-index q = 3 is used.

On the other hand, the compressive failure criterion used in this article is slightly different from that used in Huang.3,4 A compressive failure of material is considered to occur if (5.1)σeq c≤(-σu,c) where (5.2)σeq c={σ(3),σ(1)>0,σ(3)-σ(1),whenσ(1)≤0 where σu,c is the uniaxial compression strength of the material. Equation (5.2) is used to take into account an enhancement in the material load carrying capacity due to a tri-axial compression. No material buckling is assumed in this article.
It should be pointed out that equations (5.1) and (5.2) are applicable only to the resin. For the fibers, σeq c is always taken to be σ(3).

sec.title: Unloading for resin
sec.p: In some cases during an uploading process, a von Mises stress of the resin may decrease especially when some kind of residual stresses already exist before the uploading. If an initial von Mises stress has exceeded the yield stress, an unloading law should be applied.

For simplicity, the well-known unloading law11 is used in this article, as schematically shown in Figure 4. If an equivalent (von Mises) stress exceeds the yield stress (Point A on the figure), yield will take place along the curve AB. Then if an unloading occurs at Point C, the stress and strain will decrease in a linear fashion along a line CD, parallel to the linear part OA of the stress–strain curve. It should be noted that if the stress state under consideration varies from a tensile to a compressive state (or from a compressive to a tensile state) during the unloading process, the stress–strain curve used should also be changed accordingly. For instance, the stress–strain curve measured under a compression load condition should be used if the material is under an equivalent compression stress state. Whether the material is under an equivalent tension or compression stress state is determined according to the following rule2 (6){dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT Figure 4.
Schematic diagram of an unloading law.

sec.title: Isothermal analysis
sec.p:
Suppose that the laminated composite consists of a sequence of unidirectional laminae, stacking in different ply-angles. Each lamina can have different constituent materials and a different fiber volume fraction. A global coordinate system (x, y, z) is set up in such a way that x and y are located in the middle plane of the laminate and z is along the thickness direction. It is noted that the positive direction of z is downward. Let the fiber direction of the k-th lamina have an inclined ply-angle θk with the global x direction (Figure 5). Let applied load increments be denoted by dNxx, dNyy, dNzz, dNxy, dNxz and dNyz, whose positive directions are shown in Figure 6. To determine the load shared by each lamina in the laminate, a laminate theory must be employed. In the previous work,2–4 the classical laminate theory (CLT) was used for this purpose. However, the CLT is developed based on a planar stress assumption which cannot account for the stresses in the thickness direction. The present dealing is essentially a tri-axial stress state. All of the stress and strain components of the composite should be retained. Namely, we have {dσ}G = {dσxx, dσyy, dσzz, dσyz, dσxz, dσxy}T and {dε}G = {dεxx, dεyy, dεzz, 2dεyz, 2dεxz, 2dεxy}T, where G refers to a global system. Therefore, a different laminate theory must be employed. Figure 5.
Diagram for a laminated composite consisting of three unidirectional layers. Figure 6.
A laminate global coordinate system with positive applied load increments.

In developing the new laminate theory, the following two assumptions are made6,8,9: (1) the out-of-plane stress and in-plane strain components, {dσzz, dσyz, dσxz} and {dεxx, dεyy, 2dεxy}, are continuous at an interface between two adjacent layers; and (2) the in-plane stress and out-of-plane strain components, {dσxx, dσyy, dσxy} and {dεzz, 2dεyz, 2dεxz}, are continuous in each layer but discontinuous across the interface.

It is noted that all of the exercise problems are involved with either tension/compression in three orthogonal directions (the global x, y and z directions) or uniaxial tension/compression combined with shear loads (both in-plane and through thickness shear loads). There is no bending moment/lateral force applied to the laminates. The laminate lay-ups are all symmetric. Therefore, the problems can be simplified, because the curvature of each laminate is zero. All of the in-plane strains {dεxx, dεyy, 2dεxy} are the same in each layer. From the equations of equilibrium, it can be found that the out-of-plane stresses {dσzz, dσyz, dσxz} are also the same in each layer, which should be equal to the applied out-of-plane loads (denoted by forces per unit area). Hence, the 3D stress–strain relationship for the k-th lamina can be expressed in the following form6,8,9 (7){dσxx (k)dσyy (k)dσzzdσyzdσxzdσxy (k)}=([Tij]c)k[Sij]-1([Tij]c T)k{dɛxxdɛyydɛzz (k)2dɛyz (k)2dɛxz (k)2dɛxy} where (8)[Tij]c=[l1 2l2 2l3 22l2l32l3l12l1l2m1 2m2 2m3 22m2m32m3m12m1m2n1 2n2 2n3 22n2n32n3n12n1n2m1n1m2n2m3n3m2n3+m3n2n3m1+n1m3m1n2+m2n1n1l1n2l2n3l3l2n3+l3n2n3l1+n1l3l1n2+l2n1l1m1l2m2l3m3l2m3+l3m2l1m3+l3m1l1m2+l2m1] {dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT

In equations (7) the stress and strain increments with superscript (k) may vary from layer to layer, whereas the remaining, dσzz, dσyz, dσxz, dεxx, dεyy and 2dεxy, are constant throughout the laminate thickness.

For convenience of further analysis, let us re-arrange the components of {dσi}G and {dεi}G as per (9){dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT where [(Cij G)k] are rearranged from ([Tij]c)k[Sij]-1([Tij]cT)k. Thus, the in-plane equilibrium equations are given by (10){dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT

As aforementioned, the out-of-plane stress increments in each lamina of the laminate are the same and are equal to the overall applied stress increments, i.e. (11)dσyz (k)=dσyzdσxz (k)=dσxzdσzz (k)=dσzz k=1,2,…,n
Accordingly, the equilibrium equations for the out-of-plane stress increments of each layer can be expressed as (12){dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT

The quantities on the left-hand sides of equations (10) and (12) are the increments of stress resultants and stresses, which are known parameters a priori, whereas those on the right-hand sides are strain increments to be determined. There are altogether 3n + 3 equations, which can be used to determine the 3n + 3 strain increments. Once the strain increments of each layer are obtained, the stress increments of this layer in the global coordinate system are given by (13){dσ}k (G)=([Tij]c)k[Sij]k -1([Tij]c T)k{dɛ}k (G) which can be transformed into the local coordinates through (14){dσ}k=([Tij]s T)k{dσ}k (G) where [Tij]s=[l1 2l2 2l3 2l2l3l3l1l1l2m1 2m2 2m3 2m2m3m3m1m1m2n1 2n2 2n3 2n2n3n3n1n1n22m1n12m2n22m3n3m2n3+m3n2n3m1+n1m3m1n2+m2n12n1l12n2l22n3l3l2n3+l3n2n3l1+n1l3l1n2+l2n12l1m12l2m22l3m3l2m3+l3m2l1m3+l3m1l1m2+l2m1]
Substituting equation (14) into equation (1), the stress increments in the constituent fibers and resin of the k-th lamina can be obtained, respectively.

sec.title: Interfacial layer
sec.p:
It is a generally accepted assumption that a fiber-reinforced composite laminate consists of three components, i.e. fibers, resin and interfaces. The mechanical behavior of the composite is undoubtedly influenced by a status of the interfaces. During the fabrication of a multidirectional laminate, it is likely that a rich resin region may occur in between two adjacent layers. Thus, an inter-layer made of the pure resin is introduced in this article to represent the rich resin at the interface. The thickness of the interfacial layer is small and difficult to exactly measure but is chosen as 5% of that of the primary layers in general, where the primary layers refer to the fiber-reinforced composite laminae. However, the total thickness and the fiber volume fraction of the laminate are kept unchanged. This means that the original thickness and the fiber volume fraction of the primary layers should be adjusted. For a laminate made of equal thick primary layers with an equal fiber volume fraction, the thickness of the mid-layers is changed from h0 to 0.95h0 whereas their fiber volume fraction is increased from Vf 0 to (100/95)Vf 0 as shown in Figure 7. The thickness of the surface layers is changed to 0.975h0 and the fiber volume fraction becomes (100/97.5)Vf 0. It is noted that the choice of the 5% thickness has been done somewhat arbitrarily. No significant variation in the predicted ultimate strengths has been realized if the interfacial layer thickness is changed from 1% to 10% of that of the primary layers. It is further noted that the properties of an inter-layer are exactly the same as those of the resin material used for the composite. Should a laminate be made of hybrid materials containing more than one resin materials, an inter-layer will be defined to be a third isotropic material which has averaged properties from the two different resin systems upon which the two adjacent primary layers have been made. Figure 7.
Schematic diagram for a laminate containing pure resin inter-layers, in which h0 represents the initial thickness of the primary layers.

The introduction of the inter-layers is reasonable in terms of experimental evidences. The effect of an inter-layer on the laminate load carrying capacity can be classified into three aspects: (1) the stresses shared by each lamina will be changed by the introduction of the inter-layers; (2) the failure modes and the progressive failures may be more involved; and (3) due to the difference in thicknesses and fiber volume fractions between the mid-layers and the surface layers, the ultimate strength of the laminate may be affected by the total number of the plies although this effect is insignificant.

sec.title: Ultimate failure criteria
sec.p: In the previous work,2–4 an ultimate failure of the laminate was considered to occur when all of the laminae in the laminate had failed no matter whether the failures were caused by the fiber or resin failure. This ultimate failure criterion gave less correlation with experiments for the ultimate strengths of the laminates subjected to some loading conditions. Following Zinoviev,10 a different ultimate failure criterion for the laminate is used in this article: an ultimate failure of the laminate is considered to occur if and only if any single ply failure is due to that of the fibers or due to the compressive failure of the resin. That is, even though all of the plies may have failed due to a tensile failure of the resin the laminate still cannot be said to have attained an ultimate failure. However, if the failure of any one single ply is caused by the fiber or by the resin compressive failure this laminate is considered to attain an ultimate failure. It should be noted that in some loading conditions all of the plies may fail due to a tension on the resin. If such loads are continued to apply to the laminate, its ultimate failure governed by the fiber failure or resin compressive failure may not occur but its deformation may become unlimited large. In such cases, we have to use an additional criterion to detect an ultimate failure. Thus, if a strain of the laminate exceeds an ultimate value, we may consider that this laminate cannot sustain any more loads and an ultimate failure has occurred. In this article an ultimate strain value of 12% is used to control the deformation of the laminate and to detect an ultimate failure. Namely, if any strain component of the laminate in absolute value is greater than or equal to 12%, the laminate is considered to attain an ultimate failure.

sec.title: Post failure analysis
sec.p: It is seen from the failure criteria described in the section ‘Failure criteria’ that the failure of a lamina can be divided into four types, i.e. tensile and compressive failures of the fibers and the resin, respectively. Amongst, the fiber tensile, the fiber compressive, and the resin compressive failures are fatal. No further load can be sustained by a laminate once such a failure occurs. On the other hand, a tensile failure of the resin is involved with much more loading conditions and happens most often. This failure may not cause an ultimate failure of the laminate but it will change the stress/strain behavior of the laminate. Thus, a stiffness degradation should be applied after this type of failure. Many different kinds of degradation schemes have been proposed in the literature, and none of them has been strictly proven. In the present article, multiplying a factor of 0.01 with the modulus of the resin is used to deteriorate the stiffness of the failed lamina, whereas Poisson’s ratio of the resin is kept unchanged. This deterioration scheme is reasonable, because the resin generally has undergone a significant plastic deformation before failure and the hardening modulus, which is defined as a tangent to the resin stress–strain curve, of the resin at the failure must be significantly smaller than its elastic modulus. It is noted that the modulus in the instantaneous compliance matrix [Sij m] and the bridging matrix [Aij], summarized in Appendix 2, should be modified. The stiffness matrix [Cij] in equations (9) and (12) is also needed to be updated according to this degradation scheme. As the transverse and shear moduli of a lamina are predominantly influenced by the resin modulus, the use of the factor 0.01 also results in a reduction of these moduli by a similar amount. This, in turn, leads to a final failure due to an excessive strain occurred to the laminate when subjected to some loading conditions.

Finally, it deserves mentioning that in some cases especially when a laminate is subjected to a compressive load along thickness direction, a compressive failure of an inter-layer may occur first. Usually the failure of the interfacial layer is not fatal, even under a compressive load. Thus, when a compressive failure is detected for an inter-layer, the stiffness of the inter-layer is deteriorated by multiplying the factor of 0.01 with its modulus similarly as done for a resin tensile failure. However, the strains of the inter-layer may become extremely large after the stiffness degradation. Should such a case occur, a constraint is applied for an inter-layer strain in such a way that the absolute value of the strain should not be greater than 100% when the inter-layer is under compression. Any compressive strain of the inter-layer in absolute value exceeded 100% is no longer included in the calculation of the laminate strains. This 100% strain constraint is invalid for tensile or shearing strains of the interfacial layers.

sec.title: Thermal analysis
sec.p: Global thermal stress increments of the k-th lamina in the laminate due to a temperature variation are given by4 (15){dσi}kG,(T)=[(Cij G)k]{dɛj}kG,(T)-{βi}kGdT where {dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT

It is noted that the thermal expansion coefficient vector of the lamina, {αj}k, has 6 elements and should be calculated using equation (66) in Appendix 2. The stress increments by equation (15) must satisfy the following equilibrium equations (supposing no mechanical load is applied at this stage) (16){dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT and (17){ dσyzdσxzdσzz} ={ dσyz (k)dσxz (k)dσzz (k)} ={ 000} , k=1,2,…,n which give (18){dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT (19){dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT

Let {dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT represent the equivalent thermal load increments. If these loads are superposed, respectively, onto the left-hand sides of equations (10) and (12), i.e. (20){dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT (21){dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT

The resulting strain increments will contain contributions from both the thermal and the mechanical loads. Substitute these strain increments into equation (13) to obtain the stress increments shared by the k-th lamina in the global coordinate system. Once a coordinate transformation is performed through equation (14), these stress increments are further substituted into equations (1) to determine the stress increments in the constituent fiber and resin materials of the k-th lamina, respectively. All these stresses are resulted from not only the mechanical loads but also the temperature variation.

sec.title: Constituent properties
sec.p: Measured properties of the fibers, resins, and five UD laminae together with their fiber volume fractions used for the exercise problems have been supplied by the organizers.16 They are summarized in respective columns of Tables 1 to 12. The properties with thermal residual stresses incorporated are given in Tables 1 to 6, whereas Tables 7 to 12 show those without thermal residual stresses included. In this article, all of the fibers are assumed to be linearly elastic until rupture. The resins, however, are considered as elastic-plastic because the in-plane shear stress–strain curves of the five UD laminae supplied by the organizers are nonlinear. In the following simulation, all the elastic properties of the constituent materials except for the resin compressive moduli are taken to be the same as those provided by the organizers. The compressive moduli of the resins are back calculated from the initial linear segment of the compressive stress–strain curves of the laminae. However, proper bridging parameters used in this article are calibrated against the transverse and in-plane shear moduli of the laminae in such a way that the predicted moduli agree reasonably with the provided data. These parameters are listed in the respective tables.

Considering that an in situ property especially inelastic behavior of a constituent in a composite may be different from that in bulk form, the in-plane shear stress–strain curves of the laminae are used to retrieve the tensile plastic parameters of the resins. In Huang,4 the resin plastic parameters under compression were set equal to those under tension. In this article, however, these parameters are back calculated against the transverse compressive stress–strain data of the UD laminae. Similarly as done in Huang,4 eight linear segments are used to approximate the stress–strain curve of each resin material. The thus determined yield stresses and hardening moduli of the resins are listed in Tables 6 and 12.

The ultimate strength data of the constituent materials are essentially back calculated against the lamina strengths provided, as done in the previous work,4 but with some modifications. When the resin compressive strengths back calculated from the ultimate transverse compressive strengths of the UD composites are obviously smaller than those provided, 10% higher than the retrieved values are adopted in the present article. As for the resin tensile strengths, even more considerations have been made. First, let the resin tensile strengths back calculated from the longitudinal tensile strength, transverse tensile strength and in-plane shear strength be denoted by σm,T 1, σm,T 2 and σm,T 3, respectively. Then, if σm,T 1≥σm,T 2+σm,T 32, σm,T 1 is chosen as the resin tensile strength; otherwise, σm,T 2+σm,T 32 is defined as the resin tensile strength.

Finally, it is noted that as the stress–strain curves of the resins and the ultimate strengths of the constituents are back calculated from the UD composites, these properties obtained with and without thermal residual stresses incorporated are different, and are listed in Tables 1 to 6 and 7 to 12, respectively.

sec.title: Simulation of the exercise problems
sec.p: There are a total number of 12 exercise problems provided by the organizers. All of them can be analyzed using the present simulation procedure.

sec.title: Prediction of failure envelopes
sec.p: Let the composites be subjected to a fixed ratio of tri-axial load increments. At each load level, the resulting constituent stresses are checked against the failure criteria. If either of the constituent materials attains its ultimate strength, the composite is considered to have failed, and the tri-axial stresses applied on the composite corresponding to this failure can be determined. In this way, a continuous curve called a failure envelope can be plotted by varying the load ratio. Presented in the following are three kinds of failure information:(a) the first-ply or inter-layer failure envelope if any, (b) the last-ply failure envelope, and (c) failure mode (fiber or resin failure) corresponding to the last-ply failure. The failure envelopes both with and without thermal residual stresses are predicted.

sec.title: Problem 1 Resin (MY750 epoxy) subjected to combined σxx and σzz loads (with σyy = σzz)
sec.p:
The predicted results for this problem are shown in Figure 8, on which the continuous curve represents the envelope based on the material parameters with the thermal residual stresses included and the dashed one stands by that without considering the effect of the thermal stresses. The small discrepancy between the two curves is caused by the difference between the ultimate strengths of the resin which are back calculated from the lamina stress–strain curve with and without the thermal residual stresses considered. It is noted that the resin mechanical properties have been retrieved from the corresponding lamina behaviors. Whether or not the thermal stresses are assumed in the lamina will affect the retrieved resin properties, and hence the resin strength envelopes based on the different property parameters will be different. The predicted envelopes are not closed because when the resin is subjected to an equal tri-axial compression of σxx = σyy = σzz, the equivalent stress σeq c used in the failure criterion, equation (5.2), is always zero with no failure. Further, on the intersections of the envelopes with the positive horizontal axis the envelopes exhibit a discontinuous transition that corresponds to a load situation of σxx = 0 and σzz = σyy > 0. This transition is due to the use of the failure criterion (3.1) when a variation from the first equation of (3.2) to the second one occurs. The variation corresponds to a change of σxx from a negative to a positive value after a significantly large value of σzz = σyy has already been applied. The yielding stress envelope has also been plotted in the figure. It can be seen from the figure that the yield will not occur while the lamina is loaded under a hydrostatic compression or tension. Figure 8.
Predicted failure envelope of σxx vs σzz (with σyy = σzz) for Problem 1.

sec.title: Problem 2: UD T300/PR319 lamina subjected to combined σ12 and σ22 (with σ11 = σ22 = σ33) loads
sec.p:
Similarly as for Problem 1, the envelopes with and without thermal residual stresses are calculated and plotted in Figure 9. The stresses at which the resin begins to yield are also shown. It should be noted that when the hydrostatic load is relatively large (on the left hand side of Point D and on the right hand side of C), the yield may not occur before failure of the lamina. Corresponding to the present load combinations, the lamina failures are always caused by the resin tensile or compressive failure. From Figure 9, it can be seen that the lamina shear strength increases with the application of a moderate tri-axial compressive stress. This is because the compressive strength of the resin is larger than the resin tensile strength. If only a shear stress is applied to the lamina, the lamina will fail due to the tensile failure of the resin. When a hydrostatic compression load at a moderate value is applied, the tensile stress of the resin will decrease. Thus, an enhancement in the lamina shear strength can be realized at moderate values of hydrostatic compression stresses. For those points on the envelope that are at the right hand side of Point A, the failure of the resin is caused by a tensile failure. On the other hand, the segment between Point A and Point B corresponds to a resin compressive failure that is not under a tri-axial compressive stress state. Thus, Point A represents a stage where the resin stresses change their nature from being in excessive tension (i.e. due to a tensile failure) to being in excessive compression. The remaining part of the envelope (on the left hand side of Point B) represents the failures that are caused by the tri-axial compressive failure of the resin. Figure 9.
Predicted failure envelope of σ12 vs σ22 (with σ11 = σ22 = σ33) for Problem 2.

sec.title: Problem 3: Predicted failure envelope of 2ε12 versus σ22 (with σ11 = σ22 = σ33) for UD T300/PR319 lamina
sec.p:
The predicted failure envelope for this lamina (Figure 10) is similar in shape to Figure 9. It should be pointed out that in the present calculation the loads are applied in the form of stress increments. For the problem under consideration the failure envelope is not plotted by directly applying 2ε12 and σ22 (with σ11 = σ22 = σ33) as external loads. Instead, combined stresses of σ12 and σ22 (with σ11 = σ22 = σ33) are applied to the lamina, as done for problem 2. When a lamina failure ocuurs, the resulting shear strain 2ε12 is recorded, and the failure envelope is obtained in accordance with a variation in load ratios. Figure 10.
Predicted failure envelope of 2ε12 vs σ2 (with σ1 = σ2 = σ3) for Problem 3.

Similarly as for Problem 2, all of the failures for the present problem are caused by the failure of the resin. The envelope can be divided into three regions, the failure modes of which (from left to right along the envelope) are tri-axial compressive failure, bi- or uni-axial compressive failure, and tensile failure, respectively.

sec.title: Problem 5: UD E-glass/MY750 epoxy lamina subjected to combined σ22 and σ33 (with σ11 = σ33) loads
sec.p:
Figure 11 represents the predicted envelopes of σ22 versus σ33 (with σ11 = σ33) for this lamina, in which the continuous curve and dashed line represent the failure envelopes with and without thermal residual stresses respectively, whereas the curve with dots denotes the yielding envelope. Similarly as in the above problem, when the lamina is loaded under an approximate hydrostatic tension, the yield of the resin may not occur up to failure. It should be mentioned that when a hydrostatic loading is applied to the lamina, the stresses in the resin may not be in a hydrostatic status, although they are close to each other. This is why the resin still can yield under a hydrostatic compression when the applied load is large enough as shown in this problem. It is further noted that all of the failures are due to the resin failure except for the points identified by triangles where the failures are caused by the fiber compressive failure. Figure 11.
Predicted failure envelope of σ22 vs σ33 (with σ11 = σ33) for Problem 5.

It is seen from Figure 11 that the effect of thermal stresses is quite large under certain range of stress ratios, especially in the compression–compression quadrant. This is because under such load conditions, the thermal residual stresses result in an increase in the difference between the first and the third principal stresses of the resin. Thus, relatively less load is needed to cause the material to fail as per equations (5.1) and (5.2). This further illustrates in some cases thermal stresses can influence the load carrying capacity of a laminate to a large extent.

sec.title: Problem 6: UD S-glass/epoxy lamina subjected to combined σ11 and σ33 (with σ22 = σ33) loads
sec.p:
For this problem, the predicted failure envelopes of σ11 versus σ33 (with σ22 = σ33) with and without the influence of thermal residual stresses are shown in Figure 12. On the envelopes, the failures represented by the curves AB, CD (CD′) and BE (BE′) are due to the failure of the fibers, whereas those by the remaining parts are attributed to the resin failure. Similarly as aforementioned, the yield envelope consists of only two curves FG and HI, which are not closed. Figure 12.
Predicted failure envelope of σ11 vs σ33 (with σ22 = σ33) for Problem 6.

sec.title: Problem 7: UD A-S carbon/epoxy lamina subjected to combined σ11 and σ33 (with σ22 = σ33) loads
sec.p:
The predicted failure envelopes (Figure 13) are more or less similar to those shown in Figure 12. The features of final failures and yielding status are also similar to those represented by Figure 12. Namely, the failures denoted by the curves AB (AB′) and CD (CD′) are caused by the fiber failure whereas all the other failures are due to the resin failure. Figure 13.
Predicted failure envelope of σ11 vs σ33 (with σ22 = σ33) for Problem 7: (a) final failure and yielding stresses, (b) inter-layer failure and initial failure.

sec.title: Problem 8: (±35°)s E-glass/MY750 epoxy laminate subjected to combined σyy and σzz (with σxx = σzz) loads
sec.p:
Predicted envelopes of σyy versus σzz for this laminate with and without thermal residual stresses are shown in Figures 14 and 15, respectively. The final failure and yielding envelopes are plotted in Figures 14(a) and 15(a), whereas the initial and inter-layer failures are shown in Figures 14(b) and 15(b). It can be seen from the figures that the inter-layer failure curve is discontinuous because under some load combinations the final failure may occur before the inter-layer failure. The initial failure curves are also not continuous at some regions as shown in Figures 14(b) and 15(b), where the final and initial failures are coincided with each other and are caused by the resin compressive failure. On the other hand, the region CABD in Figures 14(a) and 15(a) corresponds to the failures that are due to excessive strains larger than a constraint, which is taken to be 12% in this article. The failures denoted by the triangle points on Figure 15(a) are caused by the fiber compressive failure when thermal residual stresses are not considered. Figure 14.
Predicted failure envelope of σyy vs σzz (with σxx = σzz) with thermal stresses for Problem 8: (a) final failure and yielding stresses, (b) inter-layer failure and Initial failure. Figure 15.
Predicted failure envelope of σyy vs σzz (with σxx = σzz) wihout thermal stresses for Problem 8:
(a) final failure, (b) initial and inter-layer failure of the laminate with thermal stresses, (c) initial and inter-layer failure of the laminate without thermal stresses.

Due to the introduction of the interfacial layers, the adjusted surface layers, which are the +35° plies, have a little bit higher fiber volume fraction than the adjusted mid-layers, which are the −35° plies. Hence, the +35° plies after the adjustment fail a little bit earlier than the −35° plies do. If, however, no interfacial layers are introduced, both the +35° plies and the −35° plies will fail simultaneously.

sec.title: Problem 10: (0°/90°/±45°)s IM7/8551-7 laminate subjected to combined σyz and σzz (with σyy = σxx = 0) loads
sec.p:
Figure 16(a) is the predicted final failure envelope for Problem 10. The initial and inter-layer failure evelopes with and without considering the thermal residual stresses are shown in Figure 16(b) and (c), respectively. From Figure 16(b) and (c), it can be seen that except for the region BC, the initial failure curve is almost identical with that of the final failure. Point A on all of the figures, which corresponds to a maximum sustained shear stress σyz, separates the curves into two parts, i.e. the left-hand side and the right-hand side parts. On the right side curve, the final failure is controlled by an excessive strain greater than 12%. This part of failure envelope is somewhat similar to that for Problem 2. Under the corresponding load combinations, the laminate does not subject to a fiber failure or a resin compressive failure. Only the resin tensile failures have been realized. For a UD lamina such as in Problem 2, no progressive failure is assumed without any material degradation. For the present problem, however, a stiffness discount is applied to the laminate once a lamina undergoes a tensile failure. This, in turn, results in large strains in the laminate. Thus, the ultimate failure is assumed when one of the strains in absolute value is equal to or greater than 12%. A progressive failure process is given as follows: the first-ply failure corresponds to the failure of the 0° plies, followed by the ±45° ply failure, and finally the 90° ply failure occurs. All of these ply failures are due to a resin tensile failure. On the left hand side of the curve, the final failures are caused by the resin compressive failure in the 0° plies. No initial failure different from the final failure has been observed. However, the inter-layer failure is predicted to occur before the final failure as shown in these figures. It is noted that under each combined load condition, no fiber failure has been recgonized. Figure 16.
Predicted failure envelope of σyz vs σzz (with σyy = σxx = 0) for Problem 10: (a) final failure envelopes, (b) initial and inter-layer failures of the laminate with thermal stresses, (c) initial and inter-layer failures of the laminate without thermal stresses.

It is noted that if thermal residual stresses are taken into account the resin will begin to yield before any load is applied. A resin yield stress state can be determined only without considering the thermal residual stresses. However, under different load combinations, the first yielding may occur in different plies. Thus a yielding envelope for a laminate is not plotted in the present article.

sec.title: Problem 11: (0°/90°)s IM7/8551-7 laminate subjected to combined σyz and σzz (with σyy = σxx = 0) loads
sec.p:
The predicted failure envelopes for this problem, shown in Figure 17(a) to (c), are similar to those for Problem 10. The failure features and failure modes are also similar, as described prceedingly. The only difference is in the failure sequence for those load combinations represented by the right-hand side to Point A on the figures. The present failures occur in the following order: the inter-layer failure occurs first, followed by the 0° ply failure, and the 90° plies fail finally. All of the failures are due to a resin failure. On the right hand side to Point A an excessive strain of the laminate greater than 12% in magnitude occurs, before which resin tensile failures for all the plies (both the 0° and the 90° plies) have already occured. On the other hand, on the left hand side to Point A a final failure is caused by a resin compressive failure in the surface layers (the 0° plies in the present analysis) and no intial failure has been observed except for the failure of the inter-layers. Figure 17.
Predicted failure envelopes of σyz vs σzz (with σyy = σxx = 0) for Problem 11.

sec.title: Problem 4: UD T300/PR319 lamina subjected to σ12 (for σ11 = σ22 = σ33 = −600 MPa)
sec.p:
According to the illustration by the organizers, for this problem an equal tri-axial compression σ11 = σ22 = σ33 =−600 MPa is applied first, followed by the application of a shear stress σ12 until failure. The residual stresses generated by the first application of σ11 = σ22 = σ33 = −600 MPa are listed in Table 13, whereas the shear stress–strain curve is plotted in Figure 18. From the table, it is seen that the residual stresses in the constituent materials are tri-axial with no shear stress. During the application of σ11 = σ22 = σ33 = −600 MPa, the resin material yields at a lower load level of σ11 = σ22 = σ33 = −136.60 MPa with thermal stresses included and −180.90 MPa without considering the thermal stresses. The shear stress–strain curve by the subsequent application of σ12 is nonlinear (no unloading occurs to this resin). The ultimate shear stress when considering the thermal effect is 50.9 MPa, whereas that without thermal stresses included is 49.2 MPa. The final failure of the lamina is caused by the resin compressive failure. Figure 18.
Predicted stress–strain curve, σ12–2ε12, for Problem 4. Table 1.

sec.title: Problem 9: (±35°)s E-glass/MY750 laminate subjected to σy at σzz = σxx = σyy = −100 MPa
sec.p:
A total number of four plies have been assumed for this laminate. The residual stresses in the constituents corresponding to the application of σzz = σxx = σyy = −100 MPa are listed in Table 14. On their basis, the stress–strain curves of σyy versus εxx and σyy versus εyy are shown in Figure 19. It is noted that the curves on Figure 19 do not include the contributions from the application of σzz = σxx = σyy = −100 MPa. Although in the subsequent application of σyy until rupture an unloading to the resin does occur, this unloading process is so limited that its effect on the stress–strain curves is insignificant. From the figure it can be seen that the failure stress without considering the thermal stresses is larger than that with the thermal stresses included. The final failure of the laminate is caused by the resin compressive failure of the −35° plies at σyy = −135 MPa considering thermal stresses, and at σyy = −161 MPa without thermal stresses included (not including the initial application of −100 MPa). The stress–strain curves with the contributions from the initial equal traxial application of −100 MPa are plotted in Figure 20. Figure 19.
Predicted stress–strain curve, σyy vs εxx and σyy vs εyy, for Problem 9. Figure 20.

sec.title: Problem 9b: (±35°)s E-glass/MY750 laminate subjected to σyy at σzz = σxx = −100 MPa
Problem 12: (0°/90°)s IM7/8551-7 laminate subjected to σzz for σyy = σxx = 0
sec.p:
In the analysis, four plies are used to simulate the (0°/90°)s laminate for the present problem, and the resulting stress–strain curves of σzz versus εzz, σzz versus εxx and σzz versus εyy are shown in Figure 22. From the figure it can be seen that the nonlinear characteristic of the curves is not significant up to failure and the failure stress without considering the thermal stresses is larger than that considering the thermal stresses. The insignificant nonlinearity is due to the nonlinear deformation of the resin which begins to yield at 0 MPa considering the thermal stresses and −121.50 MPa without considering the thermal stresses. The curves σzz versus εxx and σzz versus εyy almost coincide with each other and the little mismatch is due to the modification to the fiber volume fractions of the plies when the inter-layers are introduced. Information of the progressive failure process is as follows. With and without considering the thermal stresses, the laminate final failure occurs at σzz = −523.8 MPa and σzz = −706.5 MPa respectively due to the compressive failure of the resin in the 90° plies, and no initial or inter-layer failure occurs before the final failure. Figure 22.
Predicted stress–strain curves, σzz vs εzz, σzz vs εxx and σzz vs εyy, for Problem 12.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Some additional comments on the present simulation are given below.
One of the best benefits of the present micromechanics approach to composite failure and strength analysis is in that only limited property parameters of the constituent fiber and resin materials are required. This will much simplify a preparation in the material properties and input for them. In this article, only the constituent properties marked as ‘used’ in Tables 1 to 5 and Tables 7 to 11 as well as the property parameters in Tables 6 and 12 have been used, although more other data are provided by the exercise organizers. Essentially, the required property data for a constituent can be divided into two classes. The first class is of strength parameters. Only uniaxial tensile and compressive strengths are necessary. The second class is of those which are necessary to define the constituent instantaneous compliance matrix. In general, only a pair of uniaxial tension and uniaxial compression tests plus a Poisson’s ratio measurement is enough to determine all of these parameters, although at different temperatures different pairs of tests may be required. However, as in situ constituent behavior may be more or less different from that measured in bulk form, a better practice is to retrieve the constituent properties from measured stress–strain curves of the composite subjected to some unixial load conditions, as done in this article. During the retrieving, the fiber elastic parameters are taken to be the same as provided, whereas the resin properties are determined in such a way that the predicted and measured behaviors of a lamina are as close to each other as possible. As such, some of the ‘used’ resin property parameters are remarkably different from those provided.
As described in the previous work,4 the key point of the bridging model is in the bridging matrix and its determinate expressions. However, in this article the expressions of the bridging matrix elements, i.e. the elements off diagonal, are no longer explicit. They should be obtained by solving the nonlinear equations (47) in Appendix 2. Iterations are required in solving these equations and in principal an iterative difficulty may possibly occur. However, by choosing a suitable initial guess for the off diagonal bridging matrix elements or by reducing the load increment into even smaller, the iterative difficulty can be overcome in general. In this article, the initial guess for the bridging matrix at the current load step is always taken to be that at the previous load step. It is noted that if the laminate is under an elastic deformation, i.e. no resin inelasticity occurs, no iteration is required in determining the bridging matrix.
In this article, the fibers are assumed to be elastic until failure whereas the resins are assumed to be elastic-plastic. Therefore, the resin plastic parameters are important to the laminate strength prediction. Although the stress–strain curves of the resin materials have been provided by the organizers, considering that the properties of the resins may have changed when they are made into the laminates, the present predictions are carried out still based on the resin plastic parameters retrieved from the in-plane shear and transverse compressive stress–strain curves of the corresponding laminae for tensile and compressive behaviors, respectively. In addition, an unloading law for the resin has been incorporated into the bridging model in the present article. By comparing the predictions of Problem 9 with Problem 9b, it is seen that the unloading process may not affect the final strength of the laminate significantly but the stress–strain curves are influenced remarkably.
Any nonlinearity of a laminate may be resulted from two sources. One is from a progressive failure process incorporated with a stiffness discount scheme, and another is from an elastic-plastic (inelastic) deformation of the resin. The contribution from the resin inelastic deformation is treated in a unified manner by using the bridging model no matter what kind of load is applied to the laminate, as described in Huang4 and in this article. This unified treatment can be further summarized in every detail in the following steps:
The total load applied on the laminate is divided into a series of load increments, as schematically shown on the left-hand side of Figure 2.
Before the application of a new load increment, the total stress states (called internal stresses) in the fiber and resin materials of each layer are assumed, and the instantaneous compliance matrix of the layer is also known. It is noted that the fiber and resin stress states in a different layer can be different.
Based on the instantaneous compliance matrices of all the layers and the overall load increment on the laminate, the stress increments shared by each layer can be determined following the section ‘Laminate theory’.
For a specific layer, based on the resin total stress state, the resin von Mises stress can be calculated as per equation (58).
Based on the resin von Mises stress, the resin secant or tangent modulus can be determined from a uniaxial tensile or compressive stress–strain curve as though the von Mises stress were a uniaxially applied load on the resin. Whether the tensile or the compressive curve should be used depends on the sum of the resin three principal stresses (equation (6)). If the current von Mises stress is lower than the preceding von Mises stress, an unloading law may have to be applied in the determination of the resin secant modulus.
Using the secant modulus and according to the von Mises stress, the resin instantaneous compliance matrix [Sij m] can be determined as per equation (59), whereas the current bridge matrix [Aij] can be determined through equations (63), (52) to (55) and (47).
Based on the current bridging matrix, the stress increments in the resin and matrix materials due to the stress increments shared by the layer can be calculated as per equations (37) and (38), see also Figure 2.
Update the total stresses in the fiber and resin materials as per equations (2), and calculate all of their three principal stresses through equation (4) or other well-known formulas.
If the laminate has not attained an ultimate failure, go to Step b. A computer routine which can perform the aforementioned analysis steps has been developed. Description for the routine development together with all of the original computer code is provided in a separate paper,14 which may be considered as complementary to the present article.
In order to deal with triaxial loads, the laminate theory used in this article is an extension of the classical laminate theory based on a basic assumption that the in-plane strains and out-of-plane stresses are continuous at interfaces between adjacent layers, whereas the other stress and strain components are allowed to be discontinuous across the layers. The theory exhibits a quasi 3D feature. Namely, the theory is not fully 3D as a number of pre-assumptions have been made in its development, and is much simpler than a fully 3D approach such as a 3D elasticity theory based approach. However, the theory can calculate all of the six stress and strain components generated in the laminate. If the out-of-plane strains are taken to be zero and no out-of-plane loads are applied, this laminate theory deteriorates automatically to the classical laminate theory, which is essentially 2D.
Neither delamination nor defect in fiber/resin interface bonding has been considered in this article. Furthermore, no material buckling has been taken into account. To simulate a more practical fibrous composite, an incorporation of their influence may be more pertinent.

Finally, as will be shown in Kaddour and Hinton,17 the bridging model employed here is one of the few models that taken into account the effect of thermal stresses using micromechanics. The predictions made in the present article are compared in Kaddour and Hinton17 with those from other failure theories.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A total number of 12 laminated composites of different constituent materials subjected to a variety of triaxial loads are simulated in this article based on the micromechanics Bridging Model. Necessary modifications by incorporation of a quasi 3D laminate theory, a failure criterion for resin compressive failure, a failure criterion for laminate ultimate failure, and a partial stiffness discount scheme for a failed lamina have been made in the article to deal with tri-axially applied external especially compressive loads. As described previously, the most important feature of this model is in that all the stresses generated in the constituent materials due to any applied load including a temperature variation can be determined. The predicted results with and without considering thermal stress effect have been compared in the article.

sec.title: Another approach to the bridging model
Elastic theory
sec.p:
Consider a UD composite shown in Figure 23(a), a representative volume element (RVE) of which from a cross-sectional view is depicted in Figure 23(b). The composite has two constituents, fibers and resin, both of which are temporarily assumed to be isotropic and linearly elastic. Let us agree to use suffixes (superscripts or subscripts) f and m to stand by the fibers and resin respectively. According to Mori–Tanaka theory and Benveniste’s approach,12,13 the averaged stress and strain increments in the fiber and resin materials are correlated with the following relationships: (22){dɛ¯f}=[T]{dɛ¯m}, {dσ¯f}=[W]{dσ¯m} Figure 23.
Schematic diagram of (a) a unidirectional composite, and (b) cross-sectional view of a RVE for the composite.

In equations (22), the matrix [T] can be expressed upon Eshelby’s tensor and the stiffness matrices of the fiber and resin materials through13 (23)[T]=[[I]+[F][Cm]-1([Cf]-[Cm])]-1 where [F] is an Eshelby’s tensor. It is easy to show that the matrix [W] is related with [T] through (24)[W]=[Cf][T][Sm] where [S] denotes a compliance matrix of the material.

Supposing that a circular cylinder of an infinite length is embedded in an unbounded sphere, both of which are isotropic materials, the Eshelby’s tensor is found to have the following explicit form15 (25){dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT where F1111 = F1122 = F1133 = 0, F2211 = F3311 = 0.5ν/(1 − ν), F2222=F3333=12(1-v)[34+(1-2v)2],F2233=F3322=F3232=F2332=F3223=F2323=12(1-ν)[14-(1-2ν)2],F1212=F2112=F1221=F2121=F1313=F3113=F1331=F3131=0.25.

In the above, ν is Poisson’s ratio of the material. In the case that the cylinder is a fiber and the enclosure is a resin material, ν should be replaced by νm, the Poisson’s ratio of the resin material. It should be emphasized that if the fiber or the resin used cannot meet the above assumptions, the resulting Eshelby’s tensor will be different.

Instead of using the second equation of (22), let us introduce another expression (26){dσi m}=[Aij]{dσj f}, or, (27){dσ11 mdσ22 mdσ33 mdσ23 mdσ13 mdσ12 m}=[a11a12a13000a21a22a23000a31a32a33000000a44000000a55000000a66]{dσ11 fdσ22 fdσ33 fdσ23 fdσ13 fdσ12 f} where [Aij] is called a bridging matrix. Using the Eshelby’s tensor, the bridging matrix is given by (28){dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT Upon simple matrix multiplications, one obtains (29){dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT (30){dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT (31)a21=a31=EmEfvm-vf2(1-vm)(1+vm) (32){dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT (33){dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT (34)a44=GmGf+2F2323Gf-GmGf (35)a55=GmGf+2F1313Gf-GmGf (36)a66=GmGf+2F1212Gf-GmGf

Based on the bridging matrix, the stresses in the fiber and resin materials can be expressed as3 (37){dσi f}=(Vf[I]+Vm[Aij])-1{dσj}=[Bij]{dσj} (38){dσi m}=[Aij](Vf[I]+Vm[Aij])-1{dσj}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj} where {dσj} are the stress increments applied on the UD composite and [Bj]=(Vf[I]+Vm[Aij])-1. Furthermore, the compliance matrix of the UD composite is given by in Huang.3 (39)[Sij]=(Vf[Sij f]+Vm[Sij m][Aij])(Vf[I]+Vm[Aij])-1

It should be pointed out that the use of the bridging matrix given by equations (28) and (29) to (36) will have to face several problems. The most serious problem is that the resulting compliance matrix of the UD composite, given by equation (39), may not be symmetric. In fact, in order for the compliance matrix given by Equation (39) to be symmetric, a bridging matrix in equations (26) and (27) cannot be symmetric in general. This can be shown easily but the proof is omitted herein. Due to this reason, necessary modifications to the bridging matrix must be made in order that the following pre-requirements can be fulfilled: (1) the compliance matrix of the UD composite given by equation (39) is always symmetric; and (2) the UD composite is transversely isotropic so that only five independent elements occur in the bridging matrix. Let us assume that the independent bridging elements are a11, a22(=a33), a21(=a31), a32 and a55(=a66). The element a44 on the diagonal of the bridging matrix is not independent, but is determined according to the following condition (40)G23=E222(1+ν23) where E22, G23, and ν23 are the three transverse elastic constants of the UD composite.

In most cases, the fiber used has a Poisson’s ratio of about 0.2, whereas Poisson’s ratio of the resin is around 0.35. Furthermore, the fiber modulus, Ef, is much larger than the resin modulus, Em. Applying these conditions to equations (29), (31), (32) (33) and (35), a set of simplified expressions for the independent bridging elements as well as for a44 are given as follows3 (41)a11=Em/Ef (42)a21=a31=a32=0 (43)a22=a33=a44=β+(1-β)Em/Ef, 0≤β≤1 (44)a55=a66=α+(1-α)Gm/Gf, 0≤α≤1 where β and α are called bridging parameters, which can be considered as modifications to the parameters F2222 and 2F1212 to account for variations in the assumptions adopted for the fiber and resin materials and geometries. For the composites generally used, the parameters β and α can be assigned in the following ranges4 (45)β=0.3-0.6 (46)α=0.3-0.6
The other bridging elements should be determined according to the following condition (47)Sji=Sij, i,j=1,2,…,6, which gives {dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT

Furthermore, if the fiber becomes transversely isotropic, a straightforward modification on the independent bridging matrix elements can be made accordingly. It can be shown that the bridging matrix element a11 is directly related with the longitudinal modulus of the UD composite, whereas a22(=a33) and a55(= a66) are relevant to the transverse and in-plane shear moduli of the UD composite, respectively. Thus, the fiber elastic moduli in a11, a22(= a33) and a55(= a66) must be replaced by the fiber longitudinal modulus, transverse modulus, and in-plane shear modulus respectively. In other words, the independent bridging matrix elements for a UD composite made of transversely isotropic fibers and an isotropic resin are expressed by the following formulae (48)a11=Em/E11 f, (49)a21=a31=a32=0, (50)a22=a33=a44=β+(1-β)Em/E22 f, 0≤β≤1 (51)a55=a66=α+(1-α)Gm/G12 f, 0≤α≤1

Explicit expressions for five independent engineering moduli of the UD composite can be derived easily.2,3 Predicted engineering moduli of a number of UD composites by using the above-defined bridging elements have been compared with experimental data and good correlations have been found,2,3 see also Tables 1 to 5 for comparison. Especially, not only the in-plane but also the out-of-plane moduli can be predicted using this model. Take the out-of-plane shear modulus G23 as an example, the variation of G23 as a function of fiber volume fractions for all of the laminae used in this exercise has been plotted in Figure 24. Figure 24.
Variation of G23 as a function of fiber volume fractions (with resin moduli under tension).

sec.title: Plastic theory
sec.p: The plastic theory of the bridging model has been well established in Huang.2,3 Only relevant 3D formulae of the model are summarized in the following. Suppose that the fibers are linearly elastic until rupture and the resin can undergo a plastic deformation before failure. Essentially, the independent bridging elements in a whole elastic-plastic region are a straightforward extension of those given by equations (48) to (51) as3 (52)a11=Em/E11 f, (53)a21=a31=a32=0, (54)a22=a33=a44=β+(1-β)Em/E22 f, (55)a55=a66=α+(1-α)Gm/G12 f, where Em and Gm are called effective moduli of the resin and are defined by (56)Em={Em,whenσe m≤σY mET m,whenσe m>σY m (57)Gm={0.5Em/(1+νm),whenσe m≤σY mET m/3,σe m>σY m

In the above, σY m and ET m are yield strength and hardening modulus (tangent to the stress–strain curve at a plastic region) respectively, σe m is a von Mises stress of the resin given by (58){dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT

It is noted that the instantaneous compliance matrix of the resin at any load level is defined by Prandtl–Reuss theory through3 (59)[Sij m]={[Sij m]e,whenσe m≤σY m[Sij m]e+[Sij m]p,whenσe m>σY m , where [Sij m]e is an elastic component of the compliance matrix specified by the well known Hooke’s law and [Sij m]p is a plastic component defined as (60)[Sij m]p=94MT m(σe m)2[σ11 'σ11 'σ22 'σ11 'σ33 'σ11 '2σ23 'σ11 '2σ13 'σ11 '2σ12 'σ11 'σ22 'σ22 'σ33 'σ22 '2σ23 'σ22 '2σ13 'σ22 '2σ12 'σ22 'σ33 'σ33 '2σ23 'σ33 '2σ13 'σ33 '2σ13 'σ33 '4σ23 'σ33 '4σ13 'σ23 '4σ12 'σ23 '4σ13 'σ13 '4σ12 'σ13 'symmetric4σ12 'σ12 ']
With (61)MT m=EmET mEm-ET m, And (62)σij '=σij m-13(σ11 m+σ22 m+σ33 m)δij.

As the instantaneous compliance matrix of the resin may be whole occupied, a general bridging matrix [Aij] should be changed to the following form as done in Huang.3 (63)[Aij]=[a11a12a13a14a15a16a22a23a24a25a26a33a34a35a36zeroa44a45a46a55a56a66]
Except for the elements on the diagonal which are defined by equations (52), (54) and (55), all of the off-diagonal elements must be determined by solving equations (47).

sec.title: Thermal analysis
sec.p: Let T1 represent the working temperature of the composite, and T0 the reference temperature at which the internal stresses of the fibers and the resin are both known (e.g. stress-free). Due to the mismatch between the thermal expansion coefficients of the fibers and the resin, thermal residual stresses will be generated in the constituent materials during a temperature variation, dT = T1 − T0. Generally, for an actual composite the thermal stresses involved should be tri-axial. However, considering that the thickness of a laminate is much smaller than the other two dimensions (longitudinal and transverse dimensions), the laminate as well as the fibers and resin can deform through the thickness much more freely than along the other two directions during the temperature variation. Therefore, the stresses through the thickness due to an interaction of the fibers and resin during the temperature variation is so small comparing with those in the other two directions that the through thickness thermal stresses are neglected. Only the in-plane thermal stresses are considered in this article, as done in Huang.4 All of the formulae used are the same in form as those given in Huang.4 Thus, the stress increments in the constituent fibers and resin due to both mechanical and thermal loads are expressed as (64){dσi f}=[Bij]{dσj}+{bi f}dT (65){dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT in which the thermal stress concentration factors of the fiber and the resin, {bi f} and {bi m}, are extended from the solutions to the deteriorated 2D problem, details of which were given in Huang.4 Namely {dσi m}=[Aij][Bij]{dσj}+{bi m}dT where {b1 f,b2 f,b6 f}T and {b1 m,b2 m,b6 m}T are the solutions to the deteriorated 2D problem.

Similarly, the overall 3D thermal expansion coefficients of the lamina, {αi}={α1,α2,α3,0,0,α6}T, are extended from the 2D solutions, {α1,α2,α6}T, which can be obtained through the following formula (66){αi}=Vf([Sij f]-[Sij m]){bj f}+Vf{αi f}+Vm{αi m} It is noted that in a 3D case, α3 is set equal to α2. In the above, {αj f} and {αj m} are the thermal expansion coefficient vectors of the fiber and resin, respectively.
